### ---- 2.1. Querying Vectors ----

aurora_list$description

### ---- 2.3. Investigating Your Data Frame ----

## Using aurora_df from Task 1

# Print the first 3 rows
head(aurora_df, 3)

# Print value from 4th row, 1st column
aurora_df[4, 1]

# Print only the column with logical values (Is_Coastal)
aurora_df$Is_Coastal


## Logical Subsetting
# Select only coastal cities with population greater than 6 million
df_subset <- aurora_df[aurora_df$Is_Coastal & aurora_df$Population_mil > 6, ]
df_subset

## %in% Subsetting
# Select cities in either "advanced" or "developing" stage
df_subset_2 <- aurora_df[aurora_df$Development_Stage %in% c("advanced", "developing"), ]
df_subset_2


### ---- 2.4. Handling "Corrupted" Data (NA) ----

# Create a corrupted copy
df_corrupted <- aurora_df

# Introduce 3 NAs at chosen locations
df_corrupted[2, 2] <- NA   # Population_mil
df_corrupted[5, 4] <- NA   # Development_Stage
df_corrupted[6, 5] <- NA   # Density_Index

# Show corrupted dataframe
df_corrupted

# Count total number of NAs
sum(is.na(df_corrupted))

# Count NAs per column
colSums(is.na(df_corrupted))

# Calculate mean of Population_mil while ignoring NAs
mean(df_corrupted$Population_mil, na.rm = TRUE)

# Remove rows containing any NA values
df_clean <- na.omit(df_corrupted)
df_clean


### ---- 2.5. Bonus Challenge: which() ----

# Find row with highest population
highest_pop_index <- which.max(aurora_df$Population_mil)
aurora_df[highest_pop_index, ]

# Find row with lowest population
lowest_pop_index <- which.min(aurora_df$Population_mil)
aurora_df[lowest_pop_index, ]
